instruction: How effective is the multi-camera system prototype in addressing the spectral gap in UAV-based multispectral systems and deriving application-specific vegetation indices (VIs) for evaluating crop traits in agricultural applications?
Output:
The multi-camera system prototype described in the related study is effective in addressing the spectral gap in UAV-based multispectral systems. By implementing dedicated bandpass filter combinations, the system is able to capture data in the short-wave infrared (SWIR) domain, which contains key absorption features related to biomass and nitrogen (N). This allows for a sensitivity range from 600 to 1700 nm, filling the spectral gap that is typically covered by visible and near-infrared (VNIR) data.

Furthermore, the system is capable of deriving application-specific vegetation indices (VIs) using the captured data. In the study, two VIs, GnyLi and NRI, were applied to evaluate crop traits in a winter wheat field experiment. These VIs were derived from the data obtained on a single observation date.

The effectiveness of the multi-camera system prototype in deriving VIs and evaluating crop traits was assessed through regression models. The models were developed using ground truth data obtained through destructive sampling for the entire growing season. Crop heights were also derived from UAV-based RGB image data using an improved approach developed within the study.
